title: Ex-President Sarkozy Convicted for Campaign Spending Violations
content: Nicolas Sarkozy was found guilty of illegally financing his 2012 presidential bid by exceeding France’s strict electoral rules and sentenced to a year of house arrest. He said he would appeal.

title: After Knife Attack, New Zealand Criminalizes Terror Plotting
content: A law passed Thursday makes planning a terrorist attack a crime, addressing a legal loophole weeks after an ISIS sympathizer stabbed people at a supermarket.

title: Talk of Iraq Recognizing Israel Prompts Threats of Arrest or Death
content: A conference promoting normalization, organized by a little-known American group, prompted a furor, pointing to the volatility and danger in Iraqi politics.

title: Prison Riot in Ecuador Leaves More Than 100 Inmates Dead
content: The president imposed a series of emergency steps on Wednesday as gangs connected to criminal drug cartels battle for dominance inside the prison system.

title: Police Officer Sentenced to Life in Prison for Murder of Sarah Everard
content: Ms. Everard’s killing this year inspired a national call to action in Britain to address violence against women. The court heard this week how Wayne Couzens used his police ID and handcuffs in abducting her.

title: Amid Tensions With U.S., Erdogan Praises Ties With Russia
content: Meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said “there is no path back” from Turkish-Russian military deals opposed by the West.

title: In Week of Words, It Often Seemed Like the Divided Nations
content: The General Assembly speeches exalted the ideals of the United Nations but showed intransigence on many longstanding disputes and armed conflicts, some nearly as old as the organization itself.

title: U.K. Labour Leader Makes a Firm Push to the Political Center
content: Speaking at the party’s annual conference, sometimes over heckling, the Labour Party leader, Keir Starmer, signaled a clear break from the former leader, Jeremy Corbyn.

title: The Right to Health
content: Immunization mandates aren’t new. One helped win the American Revolution.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
content: Division among Democrats.

title: A regional health agency is buying millions of vaccines for Latin America.
content: The Pan American Health Organization is working to address inequities in availability by offering doses for sale to countries in need.

title: Tropical Storm Victor Forms in Eastern Atlantic
content: Victor, the 20th named storm of the busy 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, was south of the Cape Verde Islands, with maximum sustained winds of 45 miles per hour.

title: Japan’s Likely Next Prime Minister Tries to Set Himself Apart
content: Though Fumio Kishida, a ruling-party stalwart, has sought to distinguish himself from the unpopular departing prime minister, he’s struggled to connect with the public.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
content: Japan’s next prime minister.

title: The world’s top central bankers see supply chain problems prolonging inflation.
content: The heads of the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of England and Bank of Japan spoke on a joint panel Wednesday.

title: Gas Shortages Awaken Britain to Some Crucial Workers: Truck Drivers
content: Dwindling pay, poor roadside conditions and post-Brexit immigration rules have led to a critical shortage of drivers. Despite appeals, some say they are reluctant to return.

title: French Court Convicts Magazine Over Racist Portrayal of Black Lawmaker
content: The magazine caused an outcry last year after it published a fictional narrative depicting the legislator as an enslaved African.

title: Daintree Forest in Australia Is Returned to Indigenous Owners
content: The rainforest is among nearly 400,000 acres of land in northeast Australia that were handed back on Wednesday to Aboriginal people who have lived in the region for thousands of years.

title: La Palma Volcano Lava Hits Ocean, Creating a Pyramid and Toxic Gas Risks
content: The authorities told residents of the Spanish island to keep their windows shut, warning of powerful chemical reactions as molten rock meets seawater.

title: In Paris, It’s Literary Scandal Season Again
content: The Goncourt prize, a standard-bearer of the French novel known for its probity, has come under criticism over charges of conflict of interest after a juror voted to include her partner’s novel in a list of contenders.

title: Reduced to Rubble, an Afghan Village Struggles to Rebuild
content: A small village outside Ghazni found itself on a critical supply artery in war-torn Afghanistan. It paid a heavy price.

title: Japan Faces Big Problems. Its Next Leader Offers Few Bold Solutions.
content: The country’s governing party, with a stranglehold on power, bucked the wishes of the public to select a moderate mainstay.

title: Sarah Everard Was Falsely Arrested by Her Murderer, Court Hears
content: Wayne Couzens, a British police officer who pleaded guilty to the murder of Sarah Everard, used the pretense of Covid regulations to kidnap the 33-year-old as she was walking home.

title: Tunisian President Appoints Prime Minister Amid Protests Over Power Grab
content: President Kais Saied named Najla Bouden Romdhan, the country’s first female prime minister. But it may do little to dispel fears he is moving toward one-man rule of the nation where the Arab Spring began.

title: Hospitals in England relax Covid rules to try to ease a patient backlog.
In lockdown for 18 months, Singapore’s migrant workers yearn for freedom.
content: Over 90 percent of the workers who live in dormitories in the country are now fully vaccinated. They are still under tight restrictions.

title: Canada Grants Asylum to Refugees Who Sheltered Snowden in Hong Kong
content: The move ends a long period of uncertainty for a Sri Lankan family that hosted the National Security Agency contractor in their tiny apartment in 2013.

title: Do Germany’s Election Results Signal a Left Turn for Europe?
content: It is too early to tell, but the results certainly illustrate a fragmentation in politics and the growing influence of personalities.

title: Unpopulism
content: Why are Democrats talking about scrapping some of the most popular parts of their agenda?

title: Spain will allow soccer stadiums to return to 100 percent capacity.
